items.abstract: <jats:p>We consider a pair of Markov chains representing statistics of the Fisher-Wright-Moran model with mutations and drift. The chains have absorbing state at 0 and are related by the fact that some random time τ ago they were identical, evolving as a single Markov chain with values in {0,1,…}; from that time on they began to evolve independently, conditional on a state at the time of split, according to the same transition probabilities. The distribution of τ is a function of deterministic effective population size 2<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>(·). We study the impact of demographic history on the shape of the quasi-stationary distribution, conditional on nonabsorption at the margin (where one of the chains is at 0), and on the speed with which the probability mass escapes to the margin.</jats:p>
title: Quasi-stationary distributions of a pair of Markov chains related to time evolution of a DNA locus

items.abstract: <jats:p>We consider a pair of Markov chains representing statistics of the Fisher-Wright-Moran model with mutations and drift. The chains have absorbing state at 0 and are related by the fact that some random time τ ago they were identical, evolving as a single Markov chain with values in {0,1,…}; from that time on they began to evolve independently, conditional on a state at the time of split, according to the same transition probabilities. The distribution of τ is a function of deterministic effective population size 2<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>(·). We study the impact of demographic history on the shape of the quasi-stationary distribution, conditional on nonabsorption at the margin (where one of the chains is at 0), and on the speed with which the probability mass escapes to the margin.</jats:p>
title: Quasi-stationary distributions of a pair of Markov chains related to time evolution of a DNA locus

items.abstract: <jats:p>We study the evolution in time of the joint distribution of a pair of Feller processes, related by the fact that some random time ago they were identical, evolving as a single Feller process; from that time on, they began to evolve independently, conditional on a state at the time of split, according to the same Feller transition probabilities. Such processes are involved in the Fisher-Wright model: the distribution of the time counted backwards from the present to the time of split in the past is a function of deterministic but time-varying effective size 2<jats:italic>N</jats:italic> of the population from which the two processes are sampled. In terms of a corresponding family of Feller operators, assuming asymptotic stability or ergodicity of the process of mutation, we find the limit form of the distribution of such pairs of processes sampled from decaying, asymptotically constant, and growing populations. In the case where mutation is not asymptotically stable or ergodic, limit distributions are found for the distribution of relative differences.</jats:p>
title: Asymptotic behavior of a Feller evolution family involved in the Fisher-Wright model
